1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• safety and efficacy has not been established in children less than 2 years of age
  • Primary IGF-1 deficiency (Severe): initial, 0.04 to 0.08 mg/kg (40 to 80 mcg/kg) SubQ twice daily
  • Primary IGF-1 deficiency (Severe): maintenance, may increase by 0.04 mg/kg per dose; MAX 0.12 mg/kg SubQ twice daily

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• allergy or severe hypersensitivity to mecasermin (rhIGF-1) or any component of the formulation
  • growth promotion in patients with closed epiphyses
  • intravenous administration
  • neoplasia, active or suspected; discontinue therapy if evidence of malignancy subsequently develops

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• high-risk activities (eg, driving or operating machinery); limit activities within 2 to 3 hours after dosing, particularly when therapy is initiated, due to hypoglycemic effect
  • hypersensitivity and allergic reactions, including anaphylaxis, have been reported
  • hypoglycemic effect, especially in small children; administer shortly before or after a meal or snack; monitoring recommended; may require dose adjustment
  • intracranial hypertension has occurred; perform funduscopic examinations at initiation and intermittently during therapy
  • lymphoid tissue (eg, tonsillar and adenoidal) hypertrophy has occurred; monitoring recommended
  • neonates; gasping syndrome and neurologic toxicity due to benzyl alcohol preservative can occur
  • scoliosis, history; progression may occur with rapid growth due to mecasermin therapy; monitoring recommended
  • slipped capital femoral epiphysis may occur with rapid growth due to mecasermin therapy; evaluate limp or complaints of hip or knee pain
  • report suspected adverse reactions to Tercica at 1-866-837-2422 or to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site reaction, Lipohypertrophy (5% or greater)
  • Gastrointestinal:Hypertrophy of tonsils (15%)
Serious
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hypoglycemia (42%)
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Musculoskeletal:Aseptic necrosis of bone
  • Neurologic:Raised intracranial pressure, Seizure (5% or greater)
  • Respiratory:Dyspnea

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Subcutaneous
  • use syringes that are small enough to accurately withdraw dose from vial
  • administer by subcutaneous injection shortly before or after (+/- 20 minutes) a meal or snack
  • injection site should be rotated to a different site (upper arm, thigh buttock, or abdomen) with each injection to avoid lipohypertrophy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Avoid activities that require alertness (driving, machine operation) within 2 to 3 hours of dosing, particularly during therapy initiation, until a well-tolerated dose is established.
  • This drug may cause hypertrophy of tonsils, slipped upper femoral epiphysis, or injection site reactions.
  • Instruct patient to monitor for and report signs/symptoms of hypoglycemia, especially in small children.
  • Advise patient to report signs and symptoms of hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Patient should administer within 20 minutes of a meal or snack. Never give in the absence of food.
  • Teach patient proper technique and placement of injections. This drug is to be administered subcutaneously only; never give intravenously.
  • Advise patient to rotate injection sites.
